content: I've been here 40 years. Raised my children here. This is home. But it's changed - more expensive, more crowded.
participant_profile: F, 62, Retired casino cashier, naturalized citizen from Mexico, longtime voter
section: Opening: Latino Life in Las Vegas
preceding_moderator_q: Gracias por venir. Let's start with what life is like for Latinos in Las Vegas today.

content: We've been here three generations. My grandparents came for casino jobs. Now we're everywhere - professionals, business owners, not just service workers.
participant_profile: F, 48, Office manager, Henderson, Mexican-American, third generation
section: Opening: Latino Life in Las Vegas
preceding_moderator_q: Gracias por venir. Let's start with what life is like for Latinos in Las Vegas today.

content: I own a restaurant. Serving the community for 15 years. Business is harder now - costs up, workers hard to find.
participant_profile: M, 41, Restaurant owner, East Las Vegas, Guatemalan immigrant, business focus
section: Opening: Latino Life in Las Vegas
preceding_moderator_q: Gracias por venir. Let's start with what life is like for Latinos in Las Vegas today.

content: I take care of elderly people. The work is hard, the pay is low. But I'm providing for my daughters.
participant_profile: F, 44, Home health aide, Las Vegas, Salvadoran background, single mother
section: Opening: Latino Life in Las Vegas
preceding_moderator_q: Gracias por venir. Let's start with what life is like for Latinos in Las Vegas today.

content: Puerto Ricans have a different experience - we're citizens by birth. But we're still seen as "other" sometimes.
participant_profile: M, 35, Electrician, Las Vegas, Puerto Rican, union member
section: Opening: Latino Life in Las Vegas
preceding_moderator_q: Gracias por venir. Let's start with what life is like for Latinos in Las Vegas today.

content: I'm Cuban. We tend to vote differently. But the economy doesn't care about your politics - it hits everyone.

section: Opening: Latino Life in Las Vegas
preceding_moderator_q: Gracias por venir. Let's start with what life is like for Latinos in Las Vegas today.

content: Money. Can I make rent? Can I afford groceries? Gas to get to work?

content: The economy. Inflation is killing small businesses. And I can't raise prices more - customers can't afford it.

participant_profile: F, 62, Retired casino cashier, naturalized citizen from Mexico, longtime voter
section: Opening: Latino Life in Las Vegas
preceding_moderator_q: What issues are on your mind this election?

content: She's one of us. Her mother cleaned rooms at the Sands. She understands where we come from.
participant_profile: F, 62, Retired casino cashier, naturalized citizen from Mexico, longtime voter

content: She's been good for the community. Shows up, listens, actually knows our issues.
participant_profile: F, 48, Office manager, Henderson, Mexican-American, third generation

content: In education circles, she's respected. Fights for school funding.
participant_profile: F, 51, School administrator, Henderson, education focus, community leader

content: The union loves her. PRO Act, workers' rights - she's solid on labor.
participant_profile: M, 35, Electrician, Las Vegas, Puerto Rican, union member
preceding_moderator_q: Senator Sandoval is up for re-election. What do you think of her?

content: She helped with immigration stuff when my neighbor was in trouble. Not personally, but her office did.
participant_profile: F, 44, Home health aide, Las Vegas, Salvadoran background, single mother
preceding_moderator_q: Senator Sandoval is up for re-election. What do you think of her?

content: I've met her at a UNLV event. Seemed genuine, not just working a crowd.
participant_profile: F, 28, Dental hygienist, Henderson, UNLV graduate, first-generation professional
preceding_moderator_q: Senator Sandoval is up for re-election. What do you think of her?

content: For young Latinos, she represents what's possible. First Latina Senator from Nevada.
participant_profile: M, 24, UNLV student, first-time voter, second generation, politically active
preceding_moderator_q: Senator Sandoval is up for re-election. What do you think of her?

content: The economy is bad. She's Democrat, they're in power. Fair or not, she gets some blame.
participant_profile: M, 41, Restaurant owner, East Las Vegas, Guatemalan immigrant, business focus
preceding_moderator_q: Any concerns?

content: I'm more conservative. She's too far left on some things for me.
participant_profile: M, 55, Truck driver, North Las Vegas, Cuban-American, independent voter
preceding_moderator_q: Any concerns?

content: She needs to talk more about economic growth, not just worker protection. Both matter.
participant_profile: M, 32, Real estate agent, Summerlin, upwardly mobile, moderate politics
preceding_moderator_q: Any concerns?

content: She could be more visible. Sometimes feels like she disappears until election time.
participant_profile: F, 48, Office manager, Henderson, Mexican-American, third generation
preceding_moderator_q: Any concerns?

content: She's good but we need results. Promises only go so far.
participant_profile: F, 62, Retired casino cashier, naturalized citizen from Mexico, longtime voter
preceding_moderator_q: Any concerns?

content: I'm Cuban. We fled communism. When I hear "socialism" or too much government, I get nervous. I know she's not that, but...
participant_profile: M, 55, Truck driver, North Las Vegas, Cuban-American, independent voter
preceding_moderator_q: P6, you mentioned being more conservative. Tell me more.

content: I'm business owner. I don't want more regulations, more taxes. But I also don't want workers exploited. It's complicated.
participant_profile: M, 41, Restaurant owner, East Las Vegas, Guatemalan immigrant, business focus
preceding_moderator_q: P6, you mentioned being more conservative. Tell me more.

content: I vote on economics. Both parties claim to help but neither really delivers.
participant_profile: M, 32, Real estate agent, Summerlin, upwardly mobile, moderate politics
preceding_moderator_q: P6, you mentioned being more conservative. Tell me more.

content: He's Republican, business background. On paper, I should like him.
participant_profile: M, 55, Truck driver, North Las Vegas, Cuban-American, independent voter
preceding_moderator_q: What about Adam Prescott?

content: His economic message appeals to me. But then I hear other stuff...
participant_profile: M, 41, Restaurant owner, East Las Vegas, Guatemalan immigrant, business focus
preceding_moderator_q: What about Adam Prescott?

content: He talks about cutting regulations. But specifically which ones? The vague stuff is suspicious.
participant_profile: M, 32, Real estate agent, Summerlin, upwardly mobile, moderate politics
preceding_moderator_q: What about Adam Prescott?

content: He's a hotel developer. Those guys aren't friends to workers.
participant_profile: F, 48, Office manager, Henderson, Mexican-American, third generation
preceding_moderator_q: What about Adam Prescott?

content: Non-union hotels. We know what that means. Exploitation, no protections.
participant_profile: M, 35, Electrician, Las Vegas, Puerto Rican, union member
preceding_moderator_q: What about Adam Prescott?

content: He doesn't understand our community. He sees us as cheap labor, not families.
participant_profile: F, 62, Retired casino cashier, naturalized citizen from Mexico, longtime voter
preceding_moderator_q: What about Adam Prescott?

content: I don't trust him. Rich people promising to help regular people - heard that before.
participant_profile: F, 44, Home health aide, Las Vegas, Salvadoran background, single mother
preceding_moderator_q: What about Adam Prescott?

content: His education policy is vouchers. That would destroy public schools.
participant_profile: F, 51, School administrator, Henderson, education focus, community leader
preceding_moderator_q: What about Adam Prescott?

content: He says he's pro-business but he means big business. Not little guy like my clinic.
participant_profile: F, 28, Dental hygienist, Henderson, UNLV graduate, first-generation professional
preceding_moderator_q: What about Adam Prescott?

content: He's doing the Republican Latino outreach thing. "Republicans are really for you." We're not stupid.
participant_profile: M, 24, UNLV student, first-time voter, second generation, politically active
preceding_moderator_q: What about Adam Prescott?

content: [Sighs] I wish there was a reasonable Republican. He's not really that. The more I hear, the less I like.
participant_profile: M, 55, Truck driver, North Las Vegas, Cuban-American, independent voter
preceding_moderator_q: P6, you seemed interested. Still?

content: Same. I want to support business-friendly candidates but not at the expense of my workers, my community.
participant_profile: M, 41, Restaurant owner, East Las Vegas, Guatemalan immigrant, business focus
preceding_moderator_q: P6, you seemed interested. Still?

content: Democrats assume we'll vote for them. That's arrogant. Republicans assume we're socially conservative. That's stereotyping.
participant_profile: M, 24, UNLV student, first-time voter, second generation, politically active
preceding_moderator_q: Both parties are competing for Latino votes. How do you see that?

content: We're not a monolith. Mexican-American, Cuban, Puerto Rican, Salvadoran - different experiences.
participant_profile: F, 48, Office manager, Henderson, Mexican-American, third generation
preceding_moderator_q: Both parties are competing for Latino votes. How do you see that?

content: Cubans lean Republican for historical reasons. But the new Republicans are different - more extreme.
participant_profile: M, 55, Truck driver, North Las Vegas, Cuban-American, independent voter
preceding_moderator_q: Both parties are competing for Latino votes. How do you see that?

content: Puerto Ricans are American citizens but Trump threw paper towels at us. That doesn't get forgotten.
participant_profile: M, 35, Electrician, Las Vegas, Puerto Rican, union member
preceding_moderator_q: Both parties are competing for Latino votes. How do you see that?

content: The older generation, we vote for who helps us. Not party loyalty.

preceding_moderator_q: Both parties are competing for Latino votes. How do you see that?

content: Education is what motivates me. Whoever supports public schools gets my attention.

content: Immigration isn't my top issue - I'm documented, my family is - but the rhetoric matters. How they talk about us.
